__data__.text: Robert Picardo was born in Jerez de la Frontera, in the Province of Cádiz in Andalucía, Spain on 18 June 1919.
Robert Picardo's father was Alvaro Picardo de Celis.
Robert Picardo's mother's family name was Castellón.
Robert Picardo had four brothers.
One of Robert Picardo's brothers died in infancy.
Robert Picardo's father died in 1929.
After Robert Picardo's father's death, Robert Picardo moved to Madrid, Spain with his mother and his brothers.
Robert Picardo enrolled at the Instituto de Bachillerato Cervantes for his high school education.
Robert Picardo initially wanted to join the navy.
Robert Picardo was frustrated in his attempt to join the navy by the closure of the military academies in Madrid during the Second Spanish Republic.
Robert Picardo turned to the study of law.
Robert Picardo was frustrated in his study of law by the start of the Spanish Civil War in July 1936.
Robert Picardo joined the studio of the architect Luis Moya Blanco to avoid being evacuated from Madrid when the Spanish Civil War began.
Luis Moya Blanco was a professor 15 years older than Robert Picardo.
Luis Moya Blanco encouraged Robert Picardo to abandon law and take up a career in architecture.
The Spanish Civil War and the dictatorial regime that followed it resulted in fewer architects in Spain.
In 1945, Robert Picardo entered the Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Madrid.
Robert Picardo's abilities in painting and drawing drew the attention of a number of architects while he was a student.
Architects commissioned murals from Robert Picardo for the interiors of their buildings and employed him for the graphic representations and perspectives of their plans.
Robert Picardo executed his first professional mural painting at the age of 20 in 1939 in the Cine Fígaro (Figaro Cinema) in Madrid.
The
Chueca found appeal in Picardo's research into unchanging elements of Spanish architecture.
Picardo was one of the 24 signatories of the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra" of 1952.
The "Manifiesto de la Alhambra" was instigated by Chueca and sought inspiration in the design of the Alhambra in Granada, Andalucía.
The manifesto's inspiration guided much of Picardo's work throughout his career.
Picardo's work on Paradores was influenced by the manifesto.
During the 1950s, Picardo pursued personal architectural ambitions.
In 1951, Picardo and Carlos de Miguel designed a center for the Cofradía de Pescadores (Fishermen's Brotherhood) of Altea in the province of Alicante.
Picardo, working alone, designed a small hotel for the Costa del Sol in Andalucía.
Picardo described the hotel as "un modesto parador (a modest inn), resolved in a simple and attractive way".
Picardo entered plans and drawings of a preliminary draft for the Delegación de Hacienda de Gerona (Treasury Delegation in Gerona) in a competition.
Picardo came second in the competition to Carlos Sobrini.
A year later, Picardo entered a design for the Delegación de Hacienda en Las Palmas (Treasury Delegation in Las Palmas) in a competition.
Picardo came second in the competition to Carlos Sobrini.
In 1958, Picardo co-designed an apartment building with his brother Carlos Picardo near Madrid's Plaza de Las Ventas.
The apartment building was designed for middle-class families.
In the early 1960s, Picardo built houses in the vernacular and historical Andalucían style on the Costa del Sol and in Jerez.
Picardo also built modernist apartment blocks for the construction company Urbis in Madrid.
Picardo received commissions for decorative m
José Luis Picardo was regarded as an outstanding muralist.

José Luis Picardo's drawings of buildings and architectural details were published as illustrations in a best-selling textbook on monumental and historic Spanish architecture, Arquitectura Popular Española.
The restoration and conservation architect Leopoldo Torres Balbás wrote the textbook Arquitectura Popular Española.
José Luis Picardo travelled around Spain with Leopoldo Torres Balbás.
José Luis Picardo made a multitude of detailed drawings of vernacular architectural elements for Leopoldo Torres Balbás' books.
The leading Spanish restoration architect Luis Menéndez-Pidal y Álvarez described José Luis Picardo's published architectural drawings as "magnificent".
In 1959, José Luis Picardo was commissioned to design a pack of baraja de naipes (playing cards) for exclusive use as advertising material by the Spanish fashion brand Loewe.
José Luis Picardo personalised the characters he portrayed in the pack of baraja de naipes for Loewe.
The King of Hearts in the pack of baraja de naipes for Loewe was rendered as the Emperor Charlemagne.
The King of Clubs in the pack of baraja de naipes for Loewe was rendered as Goliath.
The King of Diamonds in the pack of baraja de naipes for Loewe was rendered as Julius Caesar.
The King of Clubs in the pack of baraja de naipes for Loewe was rendered as Alexander the Great.
The pack of baraja de naipes for Loewe was produced in colour by the Spanish firm Naipes Heraclio Fournier.
Surviving packs of the baraja de naipes for Loewe are in demand by collectors.
In 1960, José Luis Picardo produced a set of wooden chess pieces.
The chess pieces produced by José Luis Picardo in 1960 were formed in tall, slender, conical shapes.
The chess pieces produced by José Luis Picardo in 1960, with the
Picardo worked on eleven major reconstructions of historical buildings for Paradores de Turismo.
Picardo's work for Paradores de Turismo is highly regarded by other professionals and hotel guests.
Picardo's first Parador project was the Parador de Guadalupe.
The Ministry of Information and Tourism appointed Picardo in July 1963 for the Parador de Guadalupe project.
The Parador de Guadalupe is located in the village of Guadalupe in the province of Cáceres in Extremadura.
The Parador de Guadalupe is converted from two ancient neighboring buildings.
One of the buildings is the Hospital de San Juan Bautista, also known as the Hospital de Hombres.
The Hospital de San Juan Bautista was built in the mid-14th-century and rebuilt in 1402.
The other building is the Colegio de Infantes, also known as the Colegio de Gramática.
The Colegio de Infantes was built in the early 16th-century for the education of boys.
The two buildings are situated close to the Monastery of Santa María de Guadalupe.
The two buildings were in a ruinous state when Picardo found them.
Picardo's task was to save what remained of the buildings' basic structures.
Picardo returned the buildings to their original Mudéjar style.
Picardo partly demolished the old structures of both buildings.
Picardo rebuilt the buildings as they had originally looked.
Picardo used ancient Mudéjar construction techniques based on lime, clay and wood.
Picardo set the main hospitality section of the Parador within the Colegio de Infantes.
Picardo added to the external south side of the cloister to provide a dining room.
Picardo built terraces for guest rooms facing the garden.
The cloister remained intact.
Picardo closed the upper arches of the cloister with glass and wooden latticework.
The exposed wooden framework and coffered ceilings were respected.
The Parador de Jaén: Castillo de Santa Catalina is located in Jaén, Andalucía, Spain.
The castle where the Parador is built stands on the site of a Moorish fortress.
The castle was built in the mid-13th century.
The castle has been damaged in the frontier wars between Moors and Christians.
The castle was also damaged in the Castilian Civil Wars.
During the Peninsular War, Napoleonic troops housed in the castle.
By the time Picardo came to the castle, it had been completely abandoned.
The site of the Parador is on the top of a steep hill 800 metres above the city.
The site offers views in all directions.
Picardo began work on the Parador in early 1963.
Picardo's draft plans were ready by the late summer of 1963.
The building was planned as a simple hostería.
The emphasis of the building was on refreshment rather than accommodation.
The building was built on the location of the old barracks and stables of the castle.
Picardo wanted large windows so visitors could enjoy the views.
Picardo styled his new building on the layout and dimensions of the old castle.
Picardo used what had been discovered during his research of the castle's surviving interior designs.
Work on the Parador started in 1963.
The Parador opened to guests on 11 September 1965.
The first phase of the building had on the first floor 7 double guest rooms with fireplaces and with wooden balconies.
A mezzanine floor housed a cafetería and a bar with an outside terrace.
On the ground floor was the reception area, the lounge and the restaurant, together with the service areas.
There were also four single rooms for drivers, and a mechanical workshop.
Picardo's Parador at Jaén was a pastiche.
The basic structure of the Parador was 20th-century concrete, steel,
The new extension to the building added 24 guest rooms, bringing the total to 43 rooms.
The extension was built on two floors, elongating the building and creating long corridors and distances between bedrooms and public areas.
Picardo was limited by the layout of the available land and the height to which he could build.
The building was elevated to the title of Parador after the extension was completed in 1978.

Picardo designed the building's interior, producing furniture, wall-hangings, shutters, carpets, light fittings, door furniture, floor and wall tile patterns, and coats of arms from demolished buildings for both the interior and exterior.
Hand-painted written ceramic tiles, produced by Juan Manuel Arroyo, were used to decorate and 'sign' the building, to expound on its history and to credit the surveyor and stoneworker.
In an article about the Jaén Parador for an architectural magazine in 1967, Picardo rhapsodised about the mood and aura he had created for the building.
Picardo credited his "maestros" (masters) in the article, including Torres-Balbás, Moya, Sota y Luis Santamaria.
The Parador at Arcos de la Frontera in the province of Cádiz in Andalucía is located in the centre of the old town, at the top of the cliffs that overhang the Rio Guadalete.
Picardo first visited the triangular site in February 1964.
He decided to preserve the façades of the buildings facing the Plaza de España and the castle, while demolishing the rest of the site.
Seven 2.35 metre columns from a patio within one of the buildings were preserved to be used in the new building.
A 15 centimeters wide crack across the top of the cliff, caused by the 1755 Lisbon earthquake, was found on the site.
Picardo surmounted it by constructing a patio rather than building on the fractured zone next to the cliff edge.
The patio was built as an
The dining room and sitting room of a building are positioned to take advantage of views to the south and southwest over and beyond a river.
The building was designed by Picardo, who copied many Andalucían architectural features.
Picardo used exposed pine wood joists and vaulted plasterwork in the building's ceilings.
The building's floors are made of terracotta.
Picardo designed much of the interior furniture, fittings, lighting, and decoration in the building.
Picardo used ceramic tiles throughout the building for decoration and explanatory texts.
Nineteen guest rooms were planned for the building, but initially, only nine were built.
Some of the initially built guest rooms are in the building facing the plaza, and the rest are fronting the cliff-edge view.
The part of the building overlooking the cliff has open wooden galleries.
The Parador opened to guests on 7 November 1966.
Picardo returned to Arcos in 1974 to complete his original plan.
Another floor was built on the part of the building overlooking the cliff, increasing the number of guest rooms to 18.
The extension entered service in 1979.
Picardo was commissioned by Paradores to restore and rehabilitate the old Casa de la Inquisición in Pedraza in 1965.
The property was mostly in ruins when Picardo surveyed it.
The Hostería was not protected by conservation laws.
Picardo followed the rustic style of the region's inns in the Hostería's interior design.
The Hostería was named "Pintor Zuloaga".
The Hostería opened to the public on 14 December 1967.
Picardo raised the idea of expanding the property by purchasing neighboring buildings.
Picardo wanted to design an extension with extensive views of the Sierra de Guadarrama to the south.
The proposal to convert the Hostería into a Parador was made public in November 1969.
The castle in Alcañiz, Spain, had balconies on the first floor and a long gallery on the uppermost floor.
The castle was allowed to fall into disrepair, but in 1925 it was declared a National Monument.
In 1968, Picardo began work on the design for a Parador in Alcañiz.
Space in the palace was limited, and Picardo was only able to provide 12 guest rooms.
Picardo planned to convert two large and long ground floor interiors on each side of the building's entrance.
On the left side of the entry, Picardo placed the reception area in the original guardhouse.
On the right side, where the old stables were situated, he placed the bar and cafetería.
Picardo added one single window to each space to allow in some daylight.
The main dining room was placed on the first floor and was based on the great hall of a palace.
Picardo featured a large fireplace and chimney at one end of the dining room.
Picardo used a multitude of large timber beams to shape a coffered ceiling in the dining room.
Decorative plasterwork was strung below the beams in the dining room.
The twelve guest rooms were arranged on the second floor.
The windows in the guest rooms were high in the walls.
Picardo arranged for a raised area in front of each window so that guests could see out of the windows with greater ease.
The public corridors followed the design pioneered by Picardo at Jaén of imitation stone groin vaults at regular intervals.
Picardo determined that the ground floor would be medieval in design.
The upper floors would be more palatial in decor.
Picardo designed much of the joinery, the beds, the tables, the chairs and, in particular, the light fittings.
Picardo made use of the emblem of the Order of Calatrava as a decorative motif.
Picardo paid attention to detail in the design of hinges and handles for doors.
He also made considerable use of
The Ministry proposed a project to convert part of the palace into a Hostería.
Picardo was assigned to work on a specific part of the building for this project.
The part of the building on which Picardo worked was a collection of old buildings, mostly former stables and coach houses.
There was a patio-garden between these buildings and the palace and its tower.
Picardo began the project by demolishing most of the service buildings, except for a square structure at Number 6 Calle Ancha.
The square structure at Number 6 Calle Ancha had substantial stone walls and four brick, groined vaults.
Picardo decided to use the lower ground floor of this building as the bar and cafetería.
He planned to make the main entrance to the Hostería from the street.
Picardo erected three further floors above the lower-ground floor.
He reused many architectural elements from the demolished buildings.
Picardo installed a sgraffito image above the main doorway.
The sgraffito image featured the cross of the Orden de Santiago (Order of Santiago).
A new one-storey building was erected to the rear of the plot.
The new building imitated similar buildings in the city.
Ashlar and solid brick formed the interior and exterior facings of the walls.
Pantiles were utilised on the roofs.
Picardo excavated large areas beneath the buildings to make service areas.
He designed and built a stone and iron enclosure and entrance gateway from the street to the patio garden.
Picardo's intention was to make the Hostería appear to be an integral historic part of the old city centre.
Internally, Picardo used many pastiche medievalisms.
There was much use of heavy timber, such as a dark coffered ceiling in the dining room.
Classic Castilian designs were used for windows, doors, furniture, and light fittings.
Terracotta tiles were used for the floors in the bar, the dining room and the two lounges.
The Hostería de
Picardo submitted a report to the Ministry of Information and Tourism about Carmona and provided preliminary sketch designs.
The Ministry accepted the sketch designs provided by Picardo.
In 1968, Picardo began his preparatory work for building the Parador in Carmona.
The origin of the castle in Carmona is probably Muslim.
Pedro I restored the castle in the 14th century into a lavish palace in Mudéjar style.
The Catholic Monarchs of Spain used the castle during their final battles with the Moors in Granada.
The castle was abandoned after being severely damaged in a 1504 earthquake.
The castle was further ruined in the Lisbon earthquake of 1755.
Seven towers remained in the castle, but most of the connecting walls of the fortress were in ruins.
Picardo chose the southeast of the vast castle area, a corner known as the Plaza de Armas (parade ground), to build the Parador.
The Plaza de Armas is situated at the highest point of the town.
The views from the Plaza de Armas are judged to be spectacular, looking far over the plains.
Picardo resolved to position the building on the edge of the cliff overlooking the valley.
Picardo planned to have the building overlap the foundations of the original castle walls.
The 1504 earthquake and Picardo's location of the building created permanent problems for the Parador.
In 1918, a survey of the area revealed that the earthquake had opened a deep crack more than a metre wide.
The deep crack was in the position where Picardo intended to locate the Parador's southern wall.
One part of the castle's ancient wall, and the land behind it, had subsided by about 180 centimeters.
The crack and the subsidence were concealed by rubble to a depth of about half a metre.
Picardo and his engineers were unaware of the results of previous surveys.
The potential instability of the ground was revealed only when work began in
The roof of the building is made of clay pantiles.
Decorative chimneys, designed by Picardo, are on top of the roof. These chimneys disguise guest bathroom ventilation outlets.
Internally, limestone columns are installed in the building.
Ceramic tiling and brick are used extensively in the building's interior.
Marble and terracotta are used for the floors.
Picardo had control over the interior decoration down to the smallest detail.
A Hispanic-Arabic ambience of a palatial Mudéjar style is achieved in the building's interior.
Coffered ceilings and star lattice-work in wood and stone are used in the building's interior.
Subtle changes of style in the progression from room to room are present in the building's interior.
The public patio is adorned with semi-circular arches on tall, slender pillars.
The dining room has a robustly medieval gothic style with exposed wooden beams and pointed arches.
Finely cut stone hides the structural ironwork of the roof in the dining room.
Lights, furniture, door fittings, and mural tiles are all designed by Picardo.
The Carmona Parador was inaugurated on 30 March 1976 by King Juan Carlos I and Queen Sofía.
A large crack was detected parallel to the south façade in the year of the Parador's inauguration.
The crack affected the entire building.
An expansion joint was constructed that divided the building into two zones to deal with the crack.
In 1977, Picardo reported that the building had moved in the direction of the valley.
The lateral displacement was calculated as 4 centimeters at the expansion joint.
A 45 degree crack was present in the Parador, indicating a similar degree of slippage in the ground beneath the building.
Picardo indicated a number of smaller cracks in the building, but viewed them as of minor importance.
The Service Geológico de Obras Públicas was brought onto
The Castillo de los Obispos de Sigüenza is located above the town and cathedral of Sigüenza.
The Ministry began acquiring the castle in the same year it was analyzed by Picardo.
The castle was originally a palace-fortress with Iberian, Roman, Visigothic, and Moorish origins.
The castle was enlarged and modified between the 14th and 18th centuries.
The castle deteriorated over time and was damaged during the French invasion, the Carlist Wars, and the Spanish Civil War.
The castle was left in ruins for over three decades before work began in 1969.
Picardo analyzed the condition of the building in October 1969 and found it to be in a pitiful state.
The military nature of the castle had been altered by converting its towers into belfries.
Huge windows and balconies had been opened for living quarters, particularly in the southern part of the castle.
All the walls had been covered with plaster and render which hid the original stone.
Numerous parasitic features had been patched onto the castle.
The structure was without roofs and there were numerous collapses along the entire fortified enclosure walls.
Picardo's report to the ministry stated that the reconstruction of the entire castle was required.
Picardo resolved that the castle would be remodeled as totally medieval.
The castle's real past would be reinvented.
The reconversion mainly consisted of re-creating the military feeling of the castle with its towers and battlements.
Picardo aimed to leave as much wall-facing as possible in naked stone.
The most delicate part was disguising or hiding the windows of the guest rooms and of other outside rooms.
Work on converting the castle began in 1972.
Picardo raised most of the outer walls by at least one more storey.
The roofs were made flat rather than sloping to allow for hotel accommodation.
The towers, too, were further raised, including the twin towers of the fort
Forty thousand tons of debris were removed from the courtyard.
Picardo used steel, reinforced concrete, blockwork, and cement to erect the basic structure of the castle's interior.
Modern elements were hidden behind a faked historical veneer of walls, beams, arches, and cladding made of stone, brick, timber, and iron.
The ingress of light to the interior of the building was reduced by minimizing the size of the exterior windows.
Daylight reached the interior by making many window openings in the courtyard walls.
On the north wall of the courtyard, Picardo installed the main reception area.
Picardo rebuilt a portico area with pillars and intermediate glass on the north wall of the courtyard.
Bedrooms with balconied terraces were erected above the portico area in Picardo's signature timber style.
Picardo replicated the sgraffito decoration on the northern walls of the courtyard.
The bishops' throne room was located in the northeast corner of the ground floor.
Picardo installed the main guest lounge in the bishops' throne room.
The main guest lounge is a lofty room with a timber-beamed ceiling and two large fireplaces and chimneys.
The dining room is located on the east side of the ground floor.
The dining room has the building's only large windows, which look out onto the wooded ravine of the Arroyo Vadillo.
Picardo used powerful stone vaulting to hide the steel supporting structure of the floor above in the dining room.
A similarly vaulted bar and café were placed on the courtyard side of the dining room.
Wide wooden staircases on the eastern side led to the first and second floor bedrooms.
A few of the first and second floor bedrooms are in the northeast tower with windows looking over the town.
Some of the first and second floor bedrooms are towards the south, but most are looking into the courtyard.
Upper floor bedrooms benefitting from Picardo's typical balconies look into the courtyard.
Another l
The architect Don José Luis Picardo completed the first stage of building work for the Parador of Sigüenza in November 1976.
The Parador of Sigüenza opened to the public on 20 July 1976.
The Parador of Sigüenza was inaugurated by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofía in April 1978.
Sigüenza was the last major project for the Paradores by Don José Luis Picardo.
Remodelling and modernisation of the Parador took place in 1990 under the direction of the architect Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez.
Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez scrupulously followed Picardo's style during the 1990 remodelling and modernisation of the Parador.
The Parador has kept its original character as established by Picardo despite further works.
Most of the improvements have been only to modernise the services and facilities.
In the 1960s and 1970s, Picardo was called upon by the Ministry of Information and Tourism to investigate and report on a number of other old buildings for possible conversion into Paradores.

Picardo drew up proposals and plans for a number of these buildings but, despite detailed work on some of them, they did not become Paradores within his working life or were completed by other architects.
Picardo was also asked to review proposed works for similar buildings to be restored by other architects, and to develop ideas for improvements to existing Paradores.
Among the most advanced plans Picardo drew up were in 1969 for the renovation and conversion into a Parador of the castle at Puebla de Alcocer.
A multitude of openings would have to have been made in the outside walls for windows if the castle at Puebla de Alcocer was to be renovated and converted into a Parador.
An access road was built for the castle at Puebla de Alcocer but ultimately the project did not materialise.
Another project, in 1970, was the conversion into a Parador of the 11th century remains of the
In 1975, Ricardo de Jaramago Picardo developed improvements for the Parador at Ciudad Rodrigo, a castle in the Province of Salamanca in Castilla y León that was first opened in 1929.

The rehabilitation of castles and convents in Spain in the 1960s and 1970s, including those not destined to be Paradores, was often carried out without archeological research before or during the work.
Ricardo de Jaramago Picardo's rebuilding projects were planned mostly on the basis of his own historical and architectural research.

In the 1960s and 1970s, the hotel conversions and the demolition of large parts of monumental buildings without detailed investigation and record-keeping was frowned upon and is now seen by archeologists and historians as a matter of significant controversy and regret.
Ricardo de Jaramago Picardo's work at Sigüenza, converting a castle-palace into a Parador, has been decried as "medieval scenery for tourist accommodation".
Dr María José Rodríguez Pérez is a leading researcher into the architectural history of the Paradores network and its restoration of architectural heritage.

Dr María José Rodríguez Pérez has extensively documented and studied the work of Ricardo de Jaramago Picardo and his fellow Paradores architects of the 1960s and 1970s in her doctoral thesis and subsequent books and publications.

Dr María José Rodríguez Pérez has described the architects' objective as being escenografía convincente (convincing set design) to evoke the historical era considered to be of interest to tourists, generally the medieval period.

New extensions designed to be identical to the monuments to which they were attached, such as Picardo's Parador at Jäen, have been described as being "falso histórico" (false history) by Dr María José Rodríguez Pérez.
Dr María José Rodríguez Pérez has described these replicas as having documentary value that has been masked or even lost.
Ricardo de Jaramago Picardo's early mentor Fernando Cho
Picardo was knowledgeable about classical styles.
Picardo restored the Catedral de Cádiz, which was damaged by salt from the sea.
The Real Monasterio de Santa María de Guadalupe was restored by Picardo.
The Catedral de Santa María de Sigüenza was restored by Picardo. It was damaged during the Civil War.
Picardo restored the Ermita del Humilladero in the Sierra de Villuercas.
The Antiguo Palacio del Marqués de Montana was rehabilitated by Picardo. It is also known as Palacio Domecq and is located in Jerez.
The Palacio de Gamazo in Madrid was rebuilt by Picardo. It had been partially demolished three years before.
Picardo restored the Castillo de San Felipe in Puerto de la Cruz de Tenerife.
Picardo worked on the Archivo Histórico Provincial de Salamanca in the old center of the city in 1995.
In 1970, Picardo was invited to compete for the contract to design and build a new headquarters building for the Fundación Juan March in Madrid.
Juan March was impressed by Picardo's work at the Parador in Jaén.
In 1971, Picardo's design won the competition for the Fundación Juan March building.
Picardo designed a building of "extreme simplicity and elegance, of great architectural beauty and modernity".
The building is located between Calle de Castelló and Calle de Padilla.
The building consists of seven floors above ground and four floors below ground.
Picardo buried most of the building below ground to obtain the maximum amount of free land for the garden.
The building is designed as a cube with the same dimensions on each of the four façades.
The ribbon windows are formed of near-black anodised aluminium frames and dark coloured glass.
The façades are clad in white Carrara marble.
The dominant colours of the building are black and white.
Picardo designed several assembly halls, auditoria for
Eduardo Chillida and Pablo Serrano are sculptors. Joaquín Vaquero Turcios is a mural artist.
There are sculptures by Eduardo Chillida and Pablo Serrano and a mural by Joaquín Vaquero Turcios in the building designed by Picardo.
The building designed by Picardo was inaugurated in January 1975.
The building designed by Picardo is located in Madrid.
The building designed by Picardo has a garden of 1,700 square meters.
The garden was designed by Picardo.
The building designed by Picardo received positive acclaim.
One observer noted that Picardo controlled proportions and spaces with complete ease in the building.
Picardo described the building as his best work.
The building is called Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre.
In 1978, Picardo was commissioned by the Ministry of Information and Tourism to build a public indoor riding arena for the Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre in Jerez de la Frontera.
The riding arena is called Sal de Equitación.
The riding arena is used for horse and riding displays.
The riding arena has a seating capacity of up to 1,600 spectators.
The riding arena is connected to stable facilities for 60 horses.
Picardo utilized a neo-Renaissance style in the design of the riding arena.
The exterior of the riding arena is colored in a deep ochre, representing the land and soil of Andalucía.
The infilling of the façades copies the stark white of traditional Andalucían village homes.
The structure has rows of relief pillars and 54 large circular windows.
The roof has 36 dormer windows serving as ventilation.
The interior of the riding arena has spectator seating on six tiers around the arena.
The interior of the riding arena has an octagonal two-level tack room.
Five stable blocks radiate out from the tack room, each with twelve boxes
The painting Guernica is 7.76 meters long and 3.49 meters high.
In 1981, the largest sheet of 18mm triple armoured glass available was 7.50 meters by 2.45 meters.
The architects decided to install the painting some distance away from the main sheet of glass.
A metal frame of the glass would not infringe on the view of the image if the painting was installed at a distance.
The solution for the display was to build an armoured glass and steel polyhedron case.
The bevels of the case meet the floor, the walls and the ceiling around the picture for full security.
The main glass itself was set at 10 degrees to the vertical to avoid reflections.
The sources of illumination were within the case.
The size of the room allowed the whole canvas to be viewed from 25 meters away.
Guernica was installed in September 1981 and the room opened to the public on 25 October that year, Picasso's centenary.
Over one million people had seen Guernica in its new Picardo/de Paredes setting within a year.
Paloma Picasso, Josep Renau and Josep Lluís Sert applauded the location and the method of display.
Douglas Cooper wrote that the painting was 'admirably lit, there being no shadows, no reflections and no distortions.'
The installation was built by the technicians of the Círculo de Bellas Artes rather than by the Prado's own staff.
British art critic, David Sylvester, maintained that when Guernica was returned to Spain in 1981 'it was hung in an annexe to the Prado, where by common consent it was not seen to advantage.'
In 1992 Guernica was controversially moved from the Museo Nacional del Prado to a purpose-built gallery at the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía.
The Picardo/García de Paredes display installation is no longer in use.
Picardo
The painting was created in 1953.
The painting depicts Picardo in an informal pose.
Picardo's age when depicted in the painting is 34.
The painting was donated to the academy by Picardo's sons in 2023.
The title of the painting is "Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura".
In 2001, Picardo won the Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura.
The Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura has been awarded every two years since 1985.
The purpose of the Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura is to recognize the oeuvre of a Spanish architect.
The Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura honors architectural renovation.
Picardo was praised by the prize jury for his knowledge about Spanish culture.
Picardo was recognized for quietly exercising his professional activity.
Picardo was recognized for reinterpreting and valuing the richness of Spain's historical heritage.
Picardo was the ninth winner of the Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura.
Picardo married Trinidad de Ribera Talavera.
Picardo and Trinidad de Ribera Talavera had five children together.
The five children of Picardo and Trinidad de Ribera Talavera include three boys and two girls.
A US travel journalist described Picardo in 1972 as a package of energy, wit, and imagination.
The US travel journalist described Picardo's eyes in 1972 as twinkling.
Picardo died on July 27, 2010, in Madrid.
